text: there are more and more women who are
getting vocally interested in comic
books and also more and more minorities
who are interested in comic books and
who would like to see a broader
representation of what it means to be an
American what it means to be a superhero
the reward was Marvel is interesting
because it's the first time that a
female Muslim superhero is getting her
own ongoing comic book series Miss
Marvel started out at the beginning as a
typical all-american blond-haired
blue-eyed super person named Carol
Danvers who has now graduated to become
Captain Marvel and gotten her own
ongoing series and so we've taken the
Miss Marvel legacy and given it to an
entirely new character sixteen-year-old
Kamala Khan who is a young Pakistani
American Muslim girl living in Jersey
City going to high school and doing a
lot of the same things that ordinary
American teenagers do but she also has
to wrestle with a lot of the issues that
come up for a third culture kid who's
the child of immigrants living in the
United States
I was born in New Jersey appropriately
enough I went to college on the East
Coast at Boston University and after
graduating I moved to Cairo Egypt and
worked there as a journalist for a large
chunk of my early in mid 20s I tried to
be an atheist but I was never very good
at it and in college I became interested
in Islam and eventually decided to
convert although in my head I told
myself that I was going to keep it a
secret but after I moved to to Egypt and
I started practicing and my husband and
fell in love I I said you know what I
can't keep this a secret this is too big
a part of my life to exclude the people
I love
from this and so I ended up telling
people and it was much better than not
healthy hiding is not healthy and I'm
sure that that's something that will
play into the MS Marvel narrative as
well it can you hide should you hide who
you really are and what you really
believe
so I have two daughters ages 1 and
almost 3 and this is something that I've
really been thinking about since
becoming a mother what what icons will
they have what heroes will they look up
to as they grow up it was important to
me to have a female Muslim character
that could be aspirational we're so used
to seeing in the news that you know
Muslim women are downtrodden than need
saving and I wanted to change that I
wanted to make a story in which the
Muslim woman narrates her own life we
all need superheroes you know no matter
what age we are or where we come from I
think it's just a matter of the
superhero being the right hero for the
time and that's what I think is the in a
strange way tremendous responsibility of
writing superheroes is that they really
do reflect the times they reflect the
zeitgeist
you
